Award.AwardTitle: Understanding and Modeling the Impact of Occupant Energy Usage Characteristics in Building

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: 1132734 (Menassa). The objective of this research is to understand and model the effect of the difference in occupant energy use characteristics on total energy consumption in commercial buildings. To achieve this objective, data will be collected from public databases, real time monitoring of four buildings, and surveys of different building and occupant groups. The results will be used to develop and validate an agent based model (ABM) that simulates occupant energy use characteristics in commercial buildings. The research is targeted to result in fundamental contributions related to advancing the knowledge, understanding and modeling of occupant energy use characteristics for choosing and designing sustainable building systems. First this research explores a major problem facing building decision makers, and that is how to reconcile predicted and actual energy consumption in buildings by studying the effect of differences in occupant energy use characteristics. The second aspect of the proposed research is that it will develop, test and validate a model that studies interactions between different occupants in the buildings and their effect on energy consumption using ABM. This approach is designed to result in more accurate estimates of building performance because it will simulate occupants? energy use characteristics, schedule, as well as their location in the building at any given time during the da., and generate a list of equipment they are using to achieve reliable energy consumption estimates. Another important aspect of this model is the feedback during the building operation phase that will allow the decision maker to test energy conservation opportunities, and determine which of these will result in greatest and fastest influence on the occupants to change their energy use habits. This approach to understanding and modeling of occupant energy use characteristics focuses on the building occupants and the way they use energy, as opposed to the traditional approach that focuses on building systems and their expected energy requirements. There is a lack of information about how building occupants affect the energy consumption in buildings through their different approaches to energy usage. The results of this research are targeted to advance the knowledge related to occupant energy usage characteristics, and significantly affect the building design process. In addition, the dissemination of the project results through different media are designed to have significant impact of educating building occupants about their energy use characteristics, and its spiraling effect on the amount of energy used to support their activities. Building occupants will learn which energy usage characteristics result in significant reduction in energy usage, and how to apply this learning in their daily routines without affecting their productivity and overall wellbeing. In addition, the proposed research will incorporate student participation that is balanced as to gender, national/international representation and inclusion of underrepresented women and minorities through collaboration with the Center for the Integration of Research, Teaching and Learning (CIRTL) at the University of Wisconsin-Madison (UW). Graduate and undergraduate students will be engaged in the data collection and modeling phases. In addition, this research will provide unique opportunities for recruiting and retaining women and minority engineers through the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) and the International Engineering Studies and Programs at the University of Wisconsin - Madison. This will be supplemented by outreach to K-12 students through participation in summer activities organized by Expanding Your Horizons (EYH) Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The following are the major research outcomes from this project:

  • An Agent Based Model of Occupants Energy Use Characteristics in Commercial Buildings: The PI and her students developed the agent based model to be used for evaluating occupancy-focused interventions in commercial buildings. This model is developed by using several theories from social sciences and innovative computing techniques. The model provides a realistic way to represent the social structure of a multi-tenant commercial buildings as a group of sub-networks to truly emulate occupancy interactions (i.e., peer-pressure) within and between companies and better understand the outcome of occupancy interventions. Agent-based modeling is used to represent occupants as agents with specific energy use characteristics and belonging to different sub-network environments in a typical commercial building. This model is then used to simulate and study the effect of peer-pressure and discrete occupancy-focused interventions (e.g., energy training) on the building’s overall energy consumption. The results of such a representation can be used to better understand the impact of different social sub-networks on energy savings potential from occupancy interventions in commercial buildings.

 

  • A Coupled Energy Simulation and Agent Based Model: a preliminary framework that couples energy models with occupancy agent based model using a distributed computing environment based on the principles defined in the High-Level Architecture (HLA). Coupling energy simulation models to occupancy agent based models allows them to efficiently analyze feedback and other intervention strategies prior to actual dissemination to building occupants. In this research, CERTI HLA was selected and customized for the development of this federation. CERTI is open-sourced and has multiple language bindings (e.g. C++/JAVA/Matlab) whose flexibility is critical for scalability and extensibility.

 

  • Occupancy Characteristics Influence Coefficients in Commercial Buildings: Although occupants’ energy behaviors significantly influence energy use, related energy model inputs are rarely considered in the modeling process. In this study, occupancy influence coefficients are developed for baseline energy models in small, medium and large size buildings located in 10 weather regions across the United States (US). These influence parameters are the result of nine occupancy actions that were identified to have the highest effect on energy use in commercial buildings. These include: After-hours equipment use, Occupied and Unoccupied Hours Cooling and Heating Temperature Set points, After-hours lighting use, After-hours active HVAC system, Hot water consumption and Building Schedule.

 

  • Evaluating Impact of Extreme Occupancy Energy Use Behavior on Occupancy Interventions in Commercial Buildings: Occupancy interventions show promising but un-sustained energy savings. One possible explanation is the presence of extreme energy users in the buildings who can have an important influence on their moderate peers and revoke the benefits of occupancy interventions. Using agent-based modeling and data from actual commercial buildings, a method is developed to evaluate the influence of extreme energy users (1) on their peers and on the energy performance of commercial buildings and (2) on the effectiveness of common occupancy interventions. The parametric variations and statistical analyses performed indicated that extremism can highly affect the effectiveness of traditional occupancy interventions. In parallel, a combination of methods has shown to empower moderate energy users, helping diffuse and maintain energy conservation practices.

 

  • A Framework to Quantify Energy Savings Potential from Improved Operations of Commercial Building Stocks: this study developed a scientific approach to quantifying the energy savings potential due to improved operations of any stock of commercial buildings. The developed framework combines energy modeling techniques (i.e., Energy Plus), studies on human actions in buildings, and surveying and sampling methods. The contributions of this study to energy policy are significant as they reinforce the role of human actions in energy conservation, and support efforts to integrate operation-focused solutions in energy conservation policy frameworks. Although the framework is developed and tested on US office building stock, it is comprehensive enough that the approach can be easily replicated to account for other building stocks (e.g., at city, state or country level).

 

  • A Data Collection and Analysis Framework to Improve the Performance of Energy-Intensive Commercial Buildings: to identify and classify the sources of energy waste in buildings (e.g., whether these are occupancy related or operation related), a data collection and analysis framework to improve the performance of energy-intensive commercial buildings is developed which can be used in buildings that show large discrepancies between estimated and actual energy consumption levels. Important challenges specifically lay in understanding the influence of human actions (by occupants and facility managers) on energy use and their contribution to commonly observed high energy consumption levels. This work developed a framework to collect relevant data about building energy performance and occupancy, mine data using advanced data fusion and analysis methods, and adapt and use energy analysis methods to understand the influence of occupants on energy performance, detect inefficiencies in the operation of building systems, and propose solutions.
